docs.abstract: Apple became the first public company to be worth $1 trillion. Amazon hit the same milestone a month later, but the reasons for the e-commerce titan’s rise are more complicated.
docs.snippet: Apple became the first public company to be worth $1 trillion. Amazon hit the same milestone a month later, but the reasons for the e-commerce titan’s rise are more complicated.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple’s market value crossed a trillion dollars last month, the reason was simple: It makes devices that a lot of people are willing to spend a lot of money on.

headline.main: Amazon Hits $1,000,000,000,000 in Value, Following Apple
headline.print_headline: Amazon Is Now Second to Cross $1 Trillion Line

docs.abstract: The retailer said it would not let third-party merchants sell goods with Nazi and white nationalist symbols on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofits and lawmakers.
docs.snippet: The retailer said it would not let third-party merchants sell goods with Nazi and white nationalist symbols on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofits and lawmakers.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon said this week that it would not let third-party retailers sell products that feature Nazi and white nationalist symbolism on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofit groups and lawmakers.

headline.main: Amazon Removes Products Featuring Nazi Symbols
headline.print_headline: Amazon Removes Products Featuring Nazi Symbolism

docs.abstract: With a single scholarly article, Lina Khan, 29, has reframed decades of monopoly law.
docs.snippet: With a single scholarly article, Lina Khan, 29, has reframed decades of monopoly law.
docs.lead_paragraph: The dead books are on the top floor of Southern Methodist University’s law library.

headline.main: Amazon’s Antitrust Antagonist Has a Breakthrough Idea
headline.print_headline: Be Afraid, Jeff Bezos, Be Very Afraid

docs.abstract: Amazon said its Whole Foods stores would let customers order groceries online and pick them up in person. Walmart already offers that service at nearly 1,800 stores.
docs.snippet: Amazon said its Whole Foods stores would let customers order groceries online and pick them up in person. Walmart already offers that service at nearly 1,800 stores.
docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon has found itself in the rare position of playing catch-up with its rivals.

headline.main: Playing Catch-Up With Walmart, Amazon Offers Digital Grocery Pickup at Whole Foods
headline.print_headline: Amazon Chases Walmart on Food Pickup

docs.abstract: Booksellers on the online marketplace are charging thousands for books that normally sell for a few dollars. Authors are perplexed — and annoyed.
docs.snippet: Booksellers on the online marketplace are charging thousands for books that normally sell for a few dollars. Authors are perplexed — and annoyed.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Many booksellers on Amazon strive to sell their wares as cheaply as possible. That, after all, is usually how you make a sale in a competitive marketplace.

headline.main: Amazon’s Curious Case of the $2,630.52 Used Paperback
headline.print_headline: Why Bargain Bin Books Can List for Thousands

docs.abstract: The cloud computing market is booming, but companies are leery of relying on one tech giant. That is helping Microsoft.
docs.snippet: The cloud computing market is booming, but companies are leery of relying on one tech giant. That is helping Microsoft.
docs.lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, Thomas M. Siebel often faced skepticism when encouraging big companies to adopt internet-style cloud computing. Many companies, he said, had qualms about relying on the faraway data centers.

headline.main: Microsoft Emerges as Clear No. 2 in Cloud Computing
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Emerges as Clear No. 2 in Booming Cloud Computing Market

docs.abstract: The race to surpass the symbolic market cap is Apple’s to lose, but Amazon is increasingly giving it some stiff competition.
docs.snippet: The race to surpass the symbolic market cap is Apple’s to lose, but Amazon is increasingly giving it some stiff competition.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: The Pursuit of $1 Trillion: Amazon Closes In on Apple

docs.abstract: Shares in the United States were up slightly a day after the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index fell more than 10 percent from its recent peak.
docs.snippet: Shares in the United States were up slightly a day after the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index fell more than 10 percent from its recent peak.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Stocks in the United States were up slightly Tuesday morning after a tough day on Wall Street had sent the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index down more than 10 percent from its recent peak.

headline.main: U.S. Stocks Rebound Slightly After Tech-Driven Slump

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

byline.original: By Jack Ewing and Carlos Tejada

docs.abstract: Amid a growing call for governments to rein in the use of the technology, Microsoft became the first tech giant to join the chorus.
docs.snippet: Amid a growing call for governments to rein in the use of the technology, Microsoft became the first tech giant to join the chorus.
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Friday became the first tech giant to join a growing call for regulations to limit the use of facial recognition technology.

headline.main: Microsoft Urges Congress to Regulate Use of Facial Recognition
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Urges Rules for Facial Recognition

docs.abstract: For a week now, people have been buzzing about an article that sounded as if it had come from a high-tech spy thriller. Does it point to larger problems?
docs.snippet: For a week now, people have been buzzing about an article that sounded as if it had come from a high-tech spy thriller. Does it point to larger problems?
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Fears of the Supply Chain in China
